The properties of alumina-based graphene nanocomposites were fine-tuned using a directed self-assembly of graphene oxide and metal oxides mediated by a surfactant approach. The resultant nanostructured metal oxides were evaluated in the esterification of glycerol with acetic acid as catalysts for the esters of glycerol production. X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Raman spectroscopy and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy measurements of the self-assembled nanocomposites revealed the nanocrystalline γ-Al2O3 phase between the separated graphene lamellar nanostructures. A crumpled monolayered graphene sheet along with well dispersed Ni and Co entities on solid surface appeared by Scanning electron microscopy coupled to energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) analyses. Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) showed Ni2+, Co3+/Co2+and Al3+species and a more reduced surface oxygen species in the self-assembled solids. The addition of basic promoters such as La, Mg or Zn to the composites did not improve the catalytic properties of the solids, but combined with NiCo-alumina-based graphene nanocomposites, they had shown good activities for triacetin production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nanocomposites Graphene Alumina NiCo Catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The properties of porous alumina ceramics, bulk or supported, have long been studied for their established properties [1,2]. Among many transitions aluminas, the γ-Al2O3 phase has received much interest in catalysis because of its unique and excellent properties, such as mesostructured pore dimensions, large surface area, and acid/base characteristics, as well [3–6]. Although the benefits of being versatile for catalytic applications, the strong surface acidity in γ-Al2O3 limits its efficiency in some reactions, especially for acid-base catalyzed biofuels production [7–9]. The controversial low chemical and hydrothermal stability of alumina besides the reduced accessibility of various reactants to the acid sites of microporous γ-Al2O3 need to be improved to obtain mesoporous alumina with customized properties for specific catalytic purposes [1,5,10]. To overcome the high acidity problem, basic oxides have been added as promoters to the alumina, resulting in optimal acid site concentrations [5,8-11]. Various synthetic routes have been developed to enhance the chemical stability of porous alumina through the incorporation of graphene, humin foams and carbon nanosheets into the alumina structure to develop excellent metal oxide matrix composites [12–14]. Thus, the honeycomb lattice structure with sp2 hybridization of graphene and its derivates i.e., graphene oxide and reduced graphene oxide make graphene an excellent matrix to composite with other materials [15,16]. More specifically, graphene oxide (GO) has a two-dimensional multilayer structure with oxygen-functionalized side groups [13,17]. Under the action of these oxygen-based functional groups, GO is more dispersible in polar organic solvents and water, being an ideal base matrix for the functionalization of active components of carriers catalyst [13,15,17]. Therefore, advances in the synthetic routes to fabricate metal oxide graphene based nanocomposites showed that the self-assembly strategy result in materials with tailored morphological, acidic, textural and structural properties [13,15,16]. Moreover, the self-assembled nanocomposites take advantage of the multifaceted chemistry features of graphene. Indeed, they are characterized by having robust mesostructures that are of particular interest in acid-base catalytic reaction due to their lower susceptibility to deactivation limiting the access of the reactants to the active sites. In the present work, alumina based graphene nanocomposites possessing varied structural and morphological attributes are synthesized by self-assembly approach. Due to much lower diffusion limitations in their pore systems than conventional metal oxides, the obtained nanocomposites are applicable to esterification of glycerol with good selectivity to glycerol esters. The esterification of carboxylic acids with alcohols has gain much attention in recent years because of the commercial importance of the esters products as fine chemicals, additives and solvents [18–21]. Specifically, esterification of glycerol with acid acetic reaction is an alternative route to produce glycerol esters such as monoacetin, diacetin and triacetin esters (Fig.S1, Supplementary Materials). To date, a variety of acid-base and redox catalysts have been explored in the reaction [19,21,22]. Despite significant investigations on the acid-base catalysts, they suffer from active sites leaching and deactivation by the water produced during the reaction [8,21]. In case of redox catalysts, a more systematic examination on their catalytic properties is still lacking, when considering the extensive analysis of the metal oxides as active sites. There are attempts to use carbon-based materials as catalysts in the esterification of glycerol with acetic acid owing to their unique features, including porosity and resistance to acidic and basic media, although these materials have low recyclability [23]. On the basis of these observations, one may intuitively assume that the graphene nanosheets composed of epoxides and hydroxylates on their basal planes and carboxylates in their edges may provide an improvement of the hydrophilicity of composite against deactivation by water [24–26]. Additionally, carbon-based oxide nanocomposites, especially those composed of GO may allow composites to be chemically stable, cost effective and mechanical resistant [13,25]. Besides, GO nanosheets can trap the metal oxide active nanoparticles within the matrix to protect them from the leaching effects. Hence, the catalytic performance of the nanocomposites is assessed through the esterification of glycerol in the presence of acetic acid. In this respect, the profuse self-assembly and hydrothermal treatment methodologies allow to achieve a short nucleation and crystallization time, resulting in metal oxides nanocomposites with controlled morphology and structure with enlarged stability. The novelty of this approach is obtaining uniformly dispersed small-sized NiCo particles with high dispersion on alumina and improved chemical stability to correlate with catalytic properties for the glycerol esters production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents used for the synthesis of the nanocomposites The reagents used for the synthesis of the composites consisted of aluminum (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Al(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9%), hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, C16H33N(CH3)3Br, 99%), lanthanum (III) nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9%), magnesium (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O), zinc(II) nitrate dihydrate (Zn(NO3)2·2H2O), nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, (C6H9NO)n average mol wt. 40,000). All of the reagents were utilized as received from Sigma-Aldrich. Commercially available graphene dispersion was also purchased from Sigma Aldrich. The graphene oxide consisted of a dispersion in water having concentration of 4 mg.mL−1, which was purified by dialysis. Besides, the graphene oxide aqueous dispersion had 47 ± 5% carbon in dry mass with graphene monolayer sheet possessing diameter less than 10 µm. 2.2 Synthesis of the metal oxide graphene nanocomposites based on self-assembly approach The self-assembly approach was used to obtain metal oxide graphene nanocomposites, as described in detail elsewhere with some modifications [16,25]. About 3.25 mL of 4 mg.mL−1 graphene dispersion were mixed together with 2.73 g of CTAB into a beaker under stirring for 2 h. Then, the mixture was diluted in 5 mL of deionized water and sonicated in an ultrasound bath. Next, 0.074 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone were added to the previous reaction mixture together with 20 mL of a 0.1 mol.L−1 aluminum nitrate and lanthanum nitrate aqueous solution in equimolar amounts while vigorously stirring. After this step, the resulting brownish mixture was stirred at room temperature for additional 30 min until it reached a pH of 4. Subsequently, 10 mL of a 1 wt.% of nickel (II) nitrate and cobalt (II) nitrate solutions in equimolar amounts were added into the reaction mixture under continuous stirring at room temperature until it became a gel. The viscous gel was then placed in a Teflon lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 90 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the brownish reaction product comprising of a gel and black dots was collected and copiously washed with deionized water, followed by drying at room temperature overnight to obtain the metal oxide@graphene nanocomposite. The metal oxide graphene nanocomposite was subsequently heated at 300 °C at a heating rate of 1 °C.min −1 for 4 h under inert atmosphere. The sample was denoted as NiCoLAG, referring to NiCo-based graphene and alumina nanocomposite with 12.0 mol% of lanthanum prepared from graphene oxide. The symbols Ni and Co denote nickel and cobalt whereas the letters L, A and G represent lanthanum, aluminum and graphene, respectively. In a typical preparation of NiCoMAG graphene nanocomposite, 20 mL of a 0.1 mol.L−1 magnesium nitrate salt solution were added to graphene, together with aluminum nitrate and a 1 wt.% cobalt and nickel nitrate solution reaction mixture under stirring, in a similar fashion as described above. After stirring, the darkish purple resulting mixture was submitted to the hydrothermal treatment in a sealed autoclave for 24 h at 90 °C followed by drying step, as described previously. To finish, the obtained metal oxide graphene nanocomposite was calcined in inert atmosphere at 300 °C for 4 h. The obtained NiCoMAG nanocomposite had 12.0 mol% of magnesium. Correspondingly, the symbols Ni and Co denote nickel and cobalt whereas the letters M, A and G represent magnesium, aluminum and graphene, respectively. The NiCoZAG sample was synthesized via metal oxide graphene nanocomposite, adding zinc nitrate to the reaction mixture and following the above mentioned preparation procedures. The symbols Ni and Co denote nickel and cobalt whereas the letters Z, A and G represent zinc, aluminum and graphene, respectively. Samples without NiCo were synthesized as previously described in detail and indicated as LAG, MAG and ZAG. Here, the letters L, M, Z, A and G correspond to the lanthanum, magnesium, zinc, aluminum and graphene, respectively. The synthesis procedure of the catalysts based on the metal oxide-graphene nanocomposites is shown in the schematic diagram in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Characterizations The crystallinity and phase composition of the nanocomposites were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a DMAXB Rigaku diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation (1.5406 Å). The beam voltage and the beam current of 40 kV and 25 mA were used, respectively. The samples were scanned over a 2θ range of 10–70° at a scanning rate of 0.02° per 100 s using a Bragg-Brentano geometry. The diffraction patterns were analyzed using the Joint Committee of Powder Diffraction Standard (JCPDS). Micro-Raman spectroscopy measurements were performed with a LabRAM HR Horiba Scientific spectrometer. The Raman system was combined with a 785 nm laser diode as the excitation source. The laser line was applied on the solids for exciting the Raman spectrum at 2 mW. Raman spectra were recorded using visible light focused by a 50 times objective. The scattered light was collected by the same objective in backscattering configuration, dispersed by a monochromator to be detected by a charge coupled device (CCD). At least eight accumulations per second to collect each spectrum were performed with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The spectra were obtained in the 200–1800 cm−1 range. The micrographs of the solids were acquired by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a FEI, Quanta 200 FEG electron microscope. SEM equipment was coupled to an Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) system operating at 2 kV accelerating voltage. Prior to the analyses, the surface of the samples was coated with a thin layer of Ag/Au to improve the conductivity. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were performed with a FEI TECNAI G2 20 model instrument operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples were prepared by suspending the nanocomposites in ethanol and agitating the mixture in an ultrasonic bath. A droplet of the sample suspensions was allowed to be dried and then placed on a copper grid coated with a strong carbon film. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vertex 70 V FT-IR spectrometer. Typically, samples were diluted in dried KBr using a ratio of 1:100 for sample. Then, samples were pressed into pellets and placed in a cell made of quartz with KRS-5 windows to perform the measurements. The spectra were taken in a wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1 at a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were carried out on a Bruker spectrometer at room temperature using the X-band equipment with an operating frequency of 9.5 kHz. The amplitude modulation of 5 G and frequency modulation of 100 kHz were used. The high-field region spectra with g values corresponding to the free electron were obtained. Previously, samples were packed into an EPR sample tube equipped with a stopcock value to be treated to perform the measurements. Textural properties of the solids were analyzed by nitrogen physisorption isotherms at liquid nitrogen temperature on an ASAP 2420 (Micromeritics). Prior to nitrogen physisorption isotherms at −196 oC, desorption of the samples at 150 oC for 8 h were performed. Estimations of the surface areas and pore size distributions of the samples were obtained by applying the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and the Barrett-Joyner -Halenda (BJH) models, respectively. Chemical analyses of Ni and Co in the bulk solids were performed by Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using a Perkin-Elmer instrument. Before the analyses, about 100 mg of the samples were dispersed in aqua- regia heated at 80 °C for 1 h. Afterwards, solids were cooled to room temperature, filtered and subsequently diluted with a 1% nitric acid solution, before the ICP-OES analyses. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were taken on a Physical Electronics VersaProbe II Scanning XPS Microprobe. The Al Kα-ray radiation (1486.6 eV) was used as the X-ray excitation source. A charge neutralizer operating at a vacuum better than 10−7 Pa was used. The sample charging effects were excluded by charge reference against adventitious carbon (C 1s at 284.8 eV). An estimated error of ±0.1 eV was used for all analyses. Recorded Auger spectra for Zn and La were very weak. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation in esterification of glycerol reaction Catalytic tests of the esterification of glycerol in the presence of acetic acid were performed in a batch reactor and monitored by gas chromatography with flame ionization detector. Typically, the quartz reactor was charged with 50 mg of the catalyst and glycerol/acetic acid molar ration of 3. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred for at least 6 h at 80 °C. At the given regular time intervals, aliquots were taken from the reactor and analysed immediately with the Shimadzu GC chromatograph possessing a flame ionization detector. The recycle study was carried out to evaluate the stability of the catalysts and examined for four cycles of 24 h each run. After the first run, a 1–2.5 mg of catalyst was added in the reaction media. All of the catalytic experiments were performed in duplicate. Detailed description of the catalytic test and calculations are given in our previous reports [8,27]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural features of the solids by XRD, Raman and FTIR spectroscopy Crystalline structures of the nanocomposites are investigated by XRD. Fig. 2 a demonstrates that all solids have characteristic broad diffraction peaks with a predominance of GO at 2θ values of 26.5°. Accordingly, the crystal structure of GO suggests peaks (Fig. 2a, inset) at 2θ=11.8° (001) and 26.5° (002), matching well with graphite, in agreement with JCPDS 41-1487. Such a graphene diffraction peak at 26.5° is associated with GO layer spacing of 0.33 nm, whereas the (002) reflection possesses an interlayer distance of ca. 0.6–1.0 nm, depending on the graphite oxidation degree and water molecules intercalated into the interlayer spacing [28–30]. Although the broad diffraction peaks reveal the low crystallinity of GO, the graphene-like honeycomb lattice is preserved in the nanocomposites. The findings state that the inexistence of the diffraction peak at around at 2θ=10° in the pattern of GO along with the presence of the peak at 2θ = 26° is indicative of the reduced graphene formation [24]. This agrees with the assumptions made in this work for the nanocomposites. Based on the self-assembly mechanism [15,16], the negatively charged hydrophilic edges and hydrophobic basal plane of GO have the ability to interact with positively charged cationic CTAB surfactant molecules, which is adsorbed on the GO surface to generate rodlike micelle aggregates. Subsequent addition of the water soluble PVP under sonication results in adsorption of the polymer to the surfactant assembled surface of graphene sheets and edges forming a uniform coat onto the GO surface. This is in accordance with the syntheses of CTAB-containing intercalated GO and polymer composites [16,30]. The XRD patterns of the nanocomposites (Fig. 2a) illustrate that a very low amount of unoxided graphite remains in all solids through the characteristic reflection (002) of graphitized material along with a downshift to lower 2θ degree regions, in comparison to that of GO (Fig. 2a, inset). These changes in the nanocomposite could be indicative of the presence of GO possessing a multilayer structure with increased lattice dimensions [30,31]. Besides, Fig. 2a includes the XRD pattern of an alumina sample displaying broad peaks typical of γ-Al2O3 phase. Accordingly, XRD pattern of the γ-Al2O3 sample (Fig. 2a, inset) exhibits the reflections at 2θ values of 19.9, 33.0, 38.6, 40.0, 46.7, 61.5 and 68.1° which correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (511) and (440) planes, respectively. These crystallographic planes are indexed to be of the face centered-cubic structure Fd-3 m of γ-Al2O3 [8,11,28]. The diffraction peaks of the nanocomposites at around 2θ = 23.0, 34.1 and 60.5° (Fig. 2a) are ascribed to the presence the (111), (311) and (440) planes of the γ-Al2O3, respectively. It is worth mentioning that the addition of the cationic salts e.g., Al3+, La3+, Co2+ and Ni2+ precursors to the CTAB intercalated partially reduced GO and PVP during the synthesis of the nanocomposites, form a lamellar nanostructure by self-assembly of metal oxide cations. During the sonication and microwave operations, the localized temperature enhancement favors the partial reduction of both GO and metal oxide precursors, as found elsewhere [30,32]. A direct consequence of the hydrothermal treatment is the crystallization of metal oxide nanoparticles between the layers of graphene or graphene stacks that result in the degradation of the long-range order produced by self-assembly approach [25]. The final process of calcination causes the CTAB removal and further γ-Al2O3 nanoparticles growth, forming an interconnected nanocrystalline γ-Al2O3 layer between the graphene stacks, as evidenced by XRD (Fig. 2a). This is later confirmed by TEM. Peaks of other metal oxide phases such as ZnO, MgO, NiO, Co3O4 and La2O3 are not detected, which suggests that these phases are either in small crystalline sizes or in low amounts below to the limit detection of the XRD technique. After calcination of the nanocomposites, the XRD patterns show γ-Al2O3 with no indications of the presence of other phases. To provide more evidence on the effectiveness of the synthesis of the solids, Raman spectra of the samples are performed (Fig. 2b). In low frequencies regions, no external modes of metal oxides or metal salt precursors typically located at 200–900 cm−1 are observed. This is closely correlated to the GO bonds prevalence over the metal ones or a strong interaction between GO and the metal oxides present into the nanocomposites synthesized via self-assembly approach. Notably, all the Raman spectra of graphene-based nanocomposite samples depict two asymmetric bands at around 1350 and 1590 cm−1 corresponding to the D and G bands, respectively (Fig. 2b). This spectral information indicates the presence of GO in all samples with the D Raman band representing the (A1g) breathing modes of six-atom rings along with defects/disorders e.g., those positioned at the edges of graphitic and graphene platelets [31–34]. Moreover, the G band corresponds to the tangential stretching mode of the (E2g) phonon of the sp2 graphitized structure [33,34]. Remarkably, the Raman intensities of the samples are multiplied by a factor (Fig. 2b) owing to their low intensities. Thus, the D and G bands are observed in the amplified spectra of the samples. In graphene oxide-functionalized and possessing metal oxides, the presence of GO gives a band broadening at 1590 cm−1 as a result of the combined contributions of the PVP ring vibration and metal oxides. Particularly, the D band intensity is higher than the G band, suggesting that the solids posses a large amount of the sp3 amorphous carbon species arising from the edges and lattice defects. Figure 2b shows that the that ZAG, MAG and LAG samples have the D bands centered at a wavenumber of 1358 cm−1 whereas the G bands centered between 1550 and 1590 cm−1. Of importance, ZAG sample shows a low-intensity D band in comparison with the other nanocomposites. Moreover, the G band in the Raman spectra of graphene-based nanocomposite samples shifts to higher wavenumber values. This could be indicative of graphite amorphization during the synthesis process, as found elsewhere [34]. Importantly, the intensity ratio of the D band with respect to that of the G band (ID/IG) is suggestive of the degree of disorder and the average size of the sp2 domains. Indeed, the ID/IG peak intensity ratios have an inverse proportion to the perfection of the graphene honeycomb lattice [31]. As shown in Fig. 2b, the highest ID/IG values are 1.82, 1.65 and 1.58 for LAG, MAG and NiCoMAG, respectively. This could be representative of the improvement in the sp2 graphitized structure of the sheets because of the partial reduction of GO in these solids, as further shown by TEM. In contrast, the smallest ID/IG peak ratios obtained by the Raman spectra are 0.47, 0.58 and 1.02 for NiCoZAG, ZAG and NiCoLAG respectively. It could indicate the low defects/disorders presence in a graphitized structure for NiCoZAG and ZAG samples, in contrast to a higher ID/IG value for NiCoLAG suggesting the existence of abundant surface defects. This is later confirmed by TEM. Besides, the lowest values of the ID/IG ratios of ca. 0.47 and 0.58 for NiCoZAG and ZAG are consistent with the metal nanoparticles possessing interactions with sp2 carbon lattice of GO being embedded in the defective positions as substitutional or interstitial dopants through the construction of ``metal vacancy'' heterostructures [31]. Compared with the other samples, the ID/IG ratios increment is assigned to the reduction of graphitic domains, in reason of the functionalization of GO sheets with metal oxide nanoparticles. The FTIR spectra of the solids are illustrated in Fig. 2c. For all samples, the absorption bands assigned to the O-H stretching vibrations of physisorbed water molecules and the hydroxyl species in the GO are observable at 3351 cm−1 [35]. At 3000–2700 cm−1, two significant low intensity shoulders at around 2920 and 2854 cm−1 are associated with the absorption bands of C-H stretching groups [8,10]. Besides, common absorption bands, visible for all the samples at 1703 and 1614 cm−1, are considered as the signature band of GO [21,30,31]. Moreover, the bands at around 1703 cm−1 are due to stretching vibrations in the carboxyl group of the pristine GO, while the C-C stretching of skeletal vibrations mode of the unoxidized graphitic domains arises at 1614 cm−1 [24]. The narrow bands at 1506, 1200 and 1058 cm−1 are assigned to the existence of stretching modes of carboxyl epoxy and carbonyl groups [24,35]. These bands appear to be shifted to low wavenumbers compared to pristine GO owing to the formation of amide linkages between the carboxylic acid on GO and the terminal groups of PVP and the nanoparticles. The presence of C-N groups is later seen by XPS analysis. Another possibility is that most of the GO bands are shifted to lower wavenumbers compared to pristine GO, in reason of the probable reduction of the single layer structure in the nanosheets of GO [32]. This could be attributable to the GO aggregation between the metal oxide nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the bands of oxygenated functional groups such as carboxyl, hydroxyl, epoxy and carbonyl groups have their intensities decreased and even disappeared in nanocomposites because of the transformation of GO into reduced graphene. In short, the FTIR data confirmed that GO nanosheets are successfully modified by PVP and the metal-oxides nanoparticles, which is consistent with the XRD and Raman results. In addition, the several absorptions weak bands in the 900–500 cm−1 range in all FTIR spectra reveal vibrational modes typically due to the metal-oxygen bonds that more closely resemble the bulk γ-Al2O3 phase. It worth mentioning that it gives information about metal oxygen phases present in the nanocomposites. A more distinct feature of these bands at such wavenumbers is their low intensity compared to the bulk oxides [10,27]. Thus, the intensity of these bands remains almost equal in all solids indicating that there are fewer free Me-O bonds, as they are interacting with GO. This is also consistent with the Raman and XRD observations. 3.2 Surface morphology and composition and textural properties TEM images of LAG, MAG and ZAG samples are shown in Fig. 3 . The micrograph of the LAG nanocomposite (Fig. 3a1) reveals that numerous nanoparticles, some of them agglomerated, are fully wrapped by the single and multilayer graphene sheets. Indeed, these graphene sheets are in random orientations and high density, as shown in Fig. 3a1, inset. The high resolution image of LAG (Fig. 3a2) illustrates that the crystalline domains is due to the γ-Al2O3 formation, in agreement with XRD. Moreover, the interlayer spacing of ca. 0.41 nm could be ascribed to the turbostratic arrangement of stacked sheets of reduced graphene oxide (Fig. 3a2, inset), as found elsewhere [36]. It seems that a strong interaction between the nanoparticles and graphene sheets may occur because of the partial reduction of GO during the material synthesis, as later confirmed by XPS. For the MAG sample, dense stacked graphene sheets with wrinkles can be well distinguished in Fig. 3b1. In addition, these graphene sheets are folded in a non-uniform fashion with small particles represented as the black dots with mean diameter of 75 nm on that folded sheets (Fig. 3b2). Besides, highly crystallized domains with lattice fringes of ca. 0.28 and 0.45 nm are seen (Fig. 3b2, inset), which are ascribable to the (022) and (111) planes of γ-Al2O3. Also, these crystallized domains can also be ascribed to the graphite with an interlayer distance between 0.33 and 0.41 nm, which is related to the d-spacing of (002) crystal plane of bulk graphite with slight distortion. It is of importance to note that the synthesis process followed by calcination of the nanocomposite can form this carbon entity, as shown by Raman and FTIR spectroscopy. Previous reports on metal oxide graphene-based nanocomposites have found similar graphite planes, when self-assembling approaches are used [26]. Concurrently, ZAG is composed of ultra-thin and transparent 2D ripples (Fig. 3c1). The HRTEM image (Fig. 3c2) indicates that the nanoparticles are enveloped by the graphene sheets. The nanoparticles have diameters within the range 1–6 nm for ZAG (Fig.S2, Supplementary Materials, inset), which is found to be smaller than those of MAG and LAG. Thus, the synthesis strategy can tune the morphological and structural properties of the nanocomposites by assembling graphene sheets with the metal oxide nanoparticles. The morphological and composition analyses of the NiCo-based nanocomposites are depicted in Fig. 4 . The elemental mapping image confirms the presence of C, O, Al, Ni and Co elements in all NiCo-based samples (Fig. 4a–c), demonstrating the successful formation of nanocomposites. In addition, the elemental composition of the nanocomposites reveals that Al is the major component among the metals e.g., 38.4 and 42.9 wt.% in NiCoLAG and NiCoZAG samples, respectively (Table 1 ). This agrees with the XRD results that suggest the presence of the alumina in the samples. Particularly, NiCoMAG contains about 13.5 wt.% of aluminum on the solid surface, which is much lower than previous samples. The EDS analyses show the appearance of La, Mg and Zn elements on the surfaces of NiCoLAG, NiCoMAG and NiCoZAG, respectively (Fig. 4a1–c1). The corresponding La, Mg and Zn contents are 9.5, 2.2 and 16.2 wt.%, which suggests the prevalence of La and Zn species on the solid surface (Table 1), as further observed by XPS. The compositional analysis also indicates that C arises as the minor component in NiCoLAG and NiCoZAG, whereas NiCoMAG has 73.3 wt.% of carbon on the solid surface. Such results demonstrate that the synergistic effects of carbon and aluminum during the assembly results in the formation of the nanostructured in NiCoLAG (Fig. 4a2) and NiCoZAG (Fig. 4b2), as later seen by HRTEM and XPS. Contrary, carbon completely coats the alumina and the other nanoparticles in NiCoMAG (Fig. 4c2). The presence of Ni and Co elements is localized in some areas of the NiCoMAG surface (Fig. 4c2, inset). Besides, Ni and Co distribution on the alumina surface for NiCoLAG seems to be homogeneous, as illustrated by the small dots on the particles in Fig. 4a2, inset. Contrary, the high contents of Ni and mainly Co in an inhomogeneous distribution as in the case of NiCoZAG (Fig. 4b2, inset) is indicative of their agglomeration on the solid surface. It is important to highlight that Br appears in very low amounts in all samples as a residue of the CTAB used during the synthesis. The morphology of the nanocomposites examined by TEM images (Fig. 5 a1-c1) reveals not well-defined wavy features of graphene owing to its nanosheets. Besides heterogeneous corrugations of GO, TEM images illustrate metal oxide nanoparticles randomly decorating the crumpled layers (Fig. 5a1-c1, inset). The magnified TEM images (Fig. 5a2-c2), depicts some crystalline regions with the lattice plane distances of ca. 0.4 nm attributed to the hexagonal lattice of graphene whereas d spacings of ca. 0.22 nm corresponds to γ-Al2O3 [8]. In fact, such a structure indeed exists in all solids, as confirmed by XRD and Raman measurements. Importantly, the surface morphology of the NiCoLAG nanocomposite consisted of rough wrinkled and non-uniformly folded graphene regions (Fig. 5a1) and small particles are found attached to both sides of the graphene sheets (Fig. 5a1, inset). Contrary, NiCoZAG nanoparticles appear distant from each other, leaving some gaps between graphene sheets (Fig. 5b1). The latter sample also exhibits dark regions with plenty of severe aggregation of nanoparticles (Fig. 5b1, inset). Moreover, typical smooth wavy-shaped morphology still appears with the nanoparticles diameters of approximately 2 to 40 nm. On the other hand, a high opacity of the graphene sheets morphology is seen in the NiCoMAG nanocomposite (Fig. 5c1). Also, graphene sheets are assembled into ripples that predominantly contain well-distributed nanoparticles inside. Upon magnifying these images (Fig. 5c2), the nanoparticles sizes are nearly 2–27 nm with a significant number of the largest ones. In addition, the high resolution TEM image shows crystalline domains arising from alumina (Fig. 5c2, inset). This is consistent with the (001) d-spacing (2.3 nm) of the lamellar mesophases in graphene nanocomposites [25]. Based on TEM analysis, it is also possible to confirm that the crystallization the alumina between the graphene oxide layers or graphene stacks with the presence of lamellar nanostructures. It is notable that the MgO, La2O3 and ZnO entities are not found by TEM investigations, suggesting their possible contribution as finely dispersed intermingled oxides with alumina in such catalytic materials. This accounts for the decreased acidity of the alumina-based solids, in similar fashion as demonstrated previously [8]. One additional important point is that during the preparation of the samples, the GO partial reduction makes the NiCoLAG and NiCoMAG samples undoubtedly benefit from a strong interaction between the graphene entities and the Ni and Co nanoparticles. As a result of these interactions, these samples have the highest catalytic activities, as further shown. Textural properties of the solids are given in Fig. S3 (Fig.S3, Supplementary materials), which revealed very low surface areas and pore volumes for all solids. This is attributable to the presence of stacked graphite sheets that remain as debris on the solid surface, even after calcination. Thus, nitrogen is not accessible to the porosity of the solids, which is consistent with previous SEM-EDS results that detected a high percentage of carbon on the solid surface. 3.3 Electronic properties by EPR and XPS The electronic properties of the composites are investigated by EPR and XPS measurements. EPR is a useful tool to investigate the interactions of localized and itinerant spins in carbon-based solids [37–39]. Fig. 6 shows the EPR spectra of selected samples. EPR spectra show broad resonance lines for the three studied samples and extremely narrow signals included in all range of the magnetic field scanning investigated. Two main components in all spectra are visible at around 2500–4000 G along with a minor shoulder in the Lorentzian curves. The asymmetric broad Lorentzian lines are typical of samples possessing conduction electrons [39,40]. Moreover, these features are characteristic of the graphene-like samples represented by the Lorentzian line shape components owing to the homogeneous distribution of radical species [39–41]. The additional resonances lines are ascribable to transition-metal impurities, as observed earlier [39,42]. It is important to highlight that the broad component has a low electron-free value i.e., g value close to 2.002, which is attributed to the resonance of conductive π-carriers that propagate in the extended aromatic graphite-like structure. Also, the findings highlight the origin of these lines to Curie-like spin susceptibility, which are related to defect states namely edge/vacancy defect spins included in extended aromatic domains of reduced graphene oxide [37]. In the case of the narrow linewidth, the presence of defect-related spins arising from oxygen-centered radical species from the redox reaction of oxygenated functional groups is likely [38]. It is apparent that these lines broadening of the anisotropic signal for other paramagnetic species such as Ni2+ and Co2+ entities signals appear to be superimposed to those of graphene. More precisely, the NiO and Co3O4 nanoparticles present in all samples are identified at g values of ca. 2.2 and 2.10, respectively [8]. Due to the electronic interactions between these components and graphene oxides, the EPR signals of Ni2+ and Co2+species have weak intensities. Interestingly, EPR signal of γ-Al2O3 phase is silent, whereas the contributions of Mg2+, La3+and Zn2+ions included into the nanocomposites cannot be ruled out. Moreover, EPR spectra of the samples have similar features indicating that their magnetic properties do not change appreciably. XPS analyses are conducted to confirm the valence states and the atomic surface concentrations of the studied nanocomposites. Representative XPS survey spectrum for NiCoLAG (Fig. 7 a) exhibits O 1s, C 1s, Ni 2p, Co 2p and Al 2s signals with predominance of narrow O 1s and C 1s peaks. The high resolution C 1s spectra of all nanocomposites are fitted with three contributions having maxima at 284.8, 286.2 and 288.2 eV (Fig. 7b). The binding energy of 284.8 eV comprises the major component of the total C 1s peak area, being ascribed to the presence of C-C/C=C and C-H bonds from the surface of the graphene sheets, as well [42–44]. The binding energies values for all nanocomposites are listed in Table 2 . Moreover, the contribution of C-O bonds from alcohol and ether groups (C-OH/-C-O-C) is located at 286.2 eV, while carboxyl groups (C(O)-OH, located at 288.2 eV) are also observable [43,45]. These results are in line with those of FTIR that suggest the presence of C-H groups (stretching at around 2920 and 2854 cm−1), hydroxyl groups (OH stretching at 3400 cm−1) and carbonyl and carboxyl groups (C=O stretching at 1614 cm−1) as well as carboxyl groups (C(O)-O stretching at 1703 cm−1) from graphene sheets. All the carbon species correspond to ca. 70–79% of the atomic surface percentage remain in the solids, although there is an expected loss of oxygen groups in the nanocomposites. Besides, the π–>π* shake-up satellite from sp 2 aromatic carbon located at around 291.5 eV in the nanocomposites is also observed in some samples. Besides, the appearance of this contribution is consistent with the expected non-covalent interactions of graphene oxide involving van der Waals interaction and π–π stacking. In accordance with the findings, the presence of these species is likely in graphene-based materials [44]. Additionally, the high resolution O 1s core level (Fig. 7c) spectrum appears as an intense signal at 532.2 eV revealing that it consists of oxygen from O=C-O, C-OH, C-O-C groups and metal oxygen species [8,10]. There is no significant difference in the binding energies values for C 1s and O 1s core levels in the nanocomposites, which in fact seems that the surface of the composites has similar functionalities, although distinct basic compound are incorporated to the samples. Interestingly, the surface O/C atomic ratios are 0.12, 0.21 and 0.19 for NiCoLAG, NiCoMAG and NiCoZAG, respectively (Table 2). Owing to the existence of fewer oxygen functional groups such as alcohol, ether and carboxyl group at the edges and surface of the nanocomposites, the obtained O/C ratios clearly explain the decreased amounts of oxygen functional groups on solid surfaces confirming the partial reduction of graphene oxide sheets. Other contributions appearing in the XPS spectra at 68.4 and 400.0 eV are attributable to the Br 3d 5/2 and N 1s core levels, respectively. These contributions illustrate the C-N pyrrolic groups [37,46] and possibly C-Br bonds form cetyltrimethylammonium bromide residues, if any, have been not completely removed by the synthesis procedure. Only NiCoZAG sample does not show N 1s contribution. As the Al 2p core level signal (Fig. 7d) appears to be overlapped with the Br 3d ones in NiCoZAG and NiCoMAG samples, the Al 2s signal is recorded and appears at around 119 eV, that is indicative of the presence Al3+ species from γ-Al2O3 [47,48]. Indeed, the Al 2s core level with binding energy at 119.0 eV is commonly accepted, when used as a second internal binding energy reference to verify the presence of γ-Al2O3 phase [47]. In the case of NiCoZAG sample, the Al 2p core level signal is seen with binding energy of 74.4 eV (Table 2), which is also suggestive of alumina presence. The Zn 2p 3/2 and Mg 2p core levels for NiCoZAG and NiCoMAG samples are illustrated at 1022.2 and 50.5 eV, respectively. These peaks correspond to the Zn2+ in ZnO and Mg2+ from MgO species [8,49]. For NiCoLAG, the La 3d5/2 core level arises at 834.8 eV evidencing the presence of La3+ species in the nanocomposite, as found elsewhere [10]. Also, the atomic Mg percentage of 2% is suggestive of the magnesium assembled on the negatively charged graphene surface and alumina. Similarly, atomic surface Zn content in NiCoZAG accounts for 1% along with a very small amount of 0.71% of La in NiCoLAG. Obviously, with similar synthesis conditions, these percentages are quite different from the bulk, which could effectively be ascribed by the electronic synergic effect of La, Mg or Zn as a result of the assembly of these nanometric species with graphene and alumina. Fig. 7d depicts the high resolution Ni 2p core level spectrum with the doublet Ni 2p 3/2, Ni 2p 1/2 at 855.9 and 873.2 eV, respectively. They are associated to Ni2+ species, as found elsewhere [27]. This is consistent with the results obtained from the EPR that suggest the NiO presence in all solids. The positions of the binding energies corresponding to the Ni 2p3/2 contributions have no significant shifts, which indicate that the Ni2+ species exists in all nanocomposites with similar interactions. Also, the atomic surface composition determined by XPS indicates that Ni2+ in NiCoLAG is 1.31%, whereas the NiCoMAG and NiCoZAG values are comparably small e.g., 0.71 and 0.60%, respectively. These results indicated that the NiO exists as an isolated species in highly dispersed state in the nanocomposites. The Co 2p spectrum for NiCoZAG (Fig. 7f) is described by a Co 2p 3/2-Co 2p 1/2 doublet at 781.5 and 796.2 eV. The Co 2p3/2 binding energies for the other studied samples present similar values and are typical for the presence of Co3+ and Co2+ species as in Co3O4 [8,50,51]. It is interesting to note that the binding energy values of Co 2p 3/2 are constant for the nanocomposites, indicating that Co is found in the (III) and (II) oxidation state as in Co3O4 [27,50,51]. A reasonable explanation may therefore be that the graphene oxide dispersion could be partially reduced together with the Co species forming the Co3O4 nanoparticles, which are enwrapping by the graphene sheets. Hence, the lack of relative shift of the core-level energies is suggestive of the synthesis procedure allowing the assembly of GO nanosheets with cobalt oxide nanoparticles inside them and interacting with the other species. The surface composition reveals a much higher surface Co species contribution in NiCoLAG than that of NiCoZAG and NiCoMAG. These results agree well with EDS analyses discussed in earlier paragraphs that show a large amount of Co on NiCoLAG sample. The NiCoMAG sample holds the major values of Ni/Al and Co/Al ratios of ca.1.65 and 1.11, respectively, possibly due to the Ni and Co strongly interacting with alumina surface. This is particularly important for illustrating the NiO and Co3O4 as highly dispersed active phase and the catalytic performance towards esterification of glycerol with acetic acid reaction, which is discussed in the following section. 3.4 Esterification of glycerol with acetic acid performances The activity of all synthesized nanocomposite materials for the glycerol esters production via esterification of glycerol in the presence of acetic acid is investigated. The reaction is conducted under solvent-free conditions, which is highly desirable to avoid secondary operations for separating the catalyst and the reaction product. In addition, the blank runs are carried out in the absence of catalyst to ascertain that there is no production of glycerol esters. Among the various nanocomposites, the lowest glycerol conversions of 2.5–7.0% along with up to 87.0% selectivity to other byproducts are observed over the LAG, ZAG and MAG nanocomposites (Table 3 ). Since the reaction under study is an acid catalyzed reaction [21,22,52], they all have a poor activity because of their insufficient acidity for the protonation of the carboxyl group of acetic acid to form the intermediate product during the reaction [8,27]. It should be noted that the presence of the basic promoters e.g., La, Mg or Zn intended to decrease the acidity of alumina. However, these species may be leached from the solids, in similar fashion to the La(Mg or Zn)-containing Al2O3 catalysts [8]. Furthermore, the LAG, ZAG and MAG samples are highly selective to the by-products of the consecutive glycerol esterification reaction. In this regard, the selectivity of monoacetin and diacetin is null, while that of triacetin is in very low amounts at the expense of the oligomers formation [27]. Further, these catalysts are found to display similar selectivity to oligomers, indicating that side reactions are occurring at the expense of the esterification of glycerol with acetic acid. Under the same conditions, NiCo catalysts are found to be more active for glycerol esterification with glycerol conversions achieving 12–36% (Table 3). Also, the graphene oxide dispersion alone is not active in the reaction and, thus, the activity is related to both the NiCo redox properties and the mild surface acidity in this kind of catalysts. It is then possible, under these considerations that NiCo catalysts, which show mild surface acidity by adding basic Mg and La promoters to alumina, present high catalytic activity compared to the NiCoZAG counterpart. Examination of the selectivities after 6 h of catalytic tests indicates that diacetin e.g., 18–20% and triacetin e.g., 20–29% amounts are observable with the main products being others by-products, irrespective of the NiCo-based nanocomposite investigated. This is in good agreement with the general reaction mechanism, previously proposed for the Ni and Co catalyzed esterification of alcohol, which depicts a sequential reaction from glycerol to form monoacetin, diacetin and its further conversion to triacetin [8,23,53]. Afterwards, the transformation of triacetin to oligomers is favored by the applied reaction condition due to the presence of a competitive pathway involving the consecutive triacetin reaction with the remaining monoacetin leading to the formation other by-products. These compounds include by-products of oligomerization of triacetin with diacetin and monoacetin [27]. Thus, subsequent examinations are conducted with NiCo-based nanocomposites catalysts to improve their reaction performance. When investigating the reaction as a function of time over NiCoLAG, NiCoZAG and NiCoMAG, a gradual increase in glycerol conversion from 2% up to 12% over all solids up to a reaction time of 1 h and conversion levels are stabilized unchanged during the course of the reaction within 6 h (Fig. S4, Supplementary materials). Interestingly, the selectivity for triacetin and other increases slightly, while the selectivity for diacetin decreases slightly with extended reaction and also with both esters of glycerol achieving a plateau at 6 h (Table 3). Moreover, monoacetin is observed in a non-significant amount from the initial stage to the end of the reaction. As NiCo-based nanocomposites show good activity and selectivity for triacetin, they are selected for further investigation. The effects of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of the solids are depicted in Fig. 8 a. The variation of the reaction temperatures from 70 to 90 °C affords an expected change in activity of the catalysts. Generally, high temperatures are assumed to afford elevated glycerol conversions due to high reaction rates and the triacetin formation occurs preferentially over acid solid-based catalysts [21,22,27]. At 70 °C, NiCoLAG, NiCoMAG and NiCoZAG are all active, achieving glycerol conversions of 13, 17 and 7%, respectively. Either in the absence of the catalysts or using LAG, MAG and ZAG without NiCo active sites at 70 °C, no glycerol conversion is observed, confirming that the presence of NiCo is essential to convert glycerol at mild temperatures. The selectivities to diacetin and triacetin are high at 70 °C, although the formation of other by-products prevails over the NiCoLAG nanocomposite (Fig. 8b). In all cases, monoacetin is formed as a minor product, which suggests that monoacetin reacts with triacetin yielding the other products. These selectivities remained substantially similar for all solids investigated. On increasing the temperature to 80 °C, glycerol conversions experience an increment to values greater than 12% with similar trends for selectivity to the main product, viz., triacetin. Contrary, diacetin production undergoes a decay at 80 °C, whereas by-products are still observed. On the other hand, the catalytic conversions of the nanocomposites increased considerably when using the solids at 90 °C (Fig. 8a). At this temperature, major changes in the surfaces properties of the solid may occur, most probably due to the overproduction of the formation of other by-products (Fig. 8b). It is also worth noting that variations of the glycerol to acetic acid molar ratios from 1:2 to 1:4 (Fig.S5, supplementary materials) did not improve the glycerol conversion. At lower glycerol to acetic acid molar ratios of ca. 1:2, the esterification of glycerol with acetic acid reaction is limited by the viscosity of glycerol whereas small increment in the molar ratio of 1:3 achieved good activities. Thus, the optimum glycerol to acetic acid molar ratios molar ratio is determined to be 1:3. This is consistent with findings in the literature reporting that best catalytic performances of the solids achieved using glycerol to acetic acid molar ratios molar ratios of 1:3 [27]. Fig. 8a shows that the NiCoLAG and NiCoMAG nanocomposites give the highest activities in all catalytic tests. This could be attributed to the dispersion of NiCo nanoparticles strongly interacting with the alumina embedded in the graphene. Consequently, leaching of the active NiCo nanoparticles in the liquid reaction solution for the solvent-free esterification of glycerol reaction is unlikely at 80 °C. Thus, reactions are performed at the optimized temperature of 80 °C for further investigation. The recyclability studies in Fig. 8c demonstrate that the activities of the catalysts are strongly dependent on the nature of the oxides in the nanocomposites. In almost all experiments, the nanocomposites are completely deactivated by the end of this reaction period, although triacetin selectivity is predominant over all solids. After carrying out the reaction for 24 h of reaction, NiCoZAG deactivates in the first use probably due to the leaching of NiCo nanoparticles. Previously, SEM-EDS suggested an inhomogeneous distribution of these particles on solid surface, which could be leached after the reaction. In the case of NiCoMAG, a loss of activity is seen only in the second cycle i.e., 48 h of reaction. This is indicative that the addition of basic Mg and Zn promoters also has a detrimental effect on the catalyst activity by reducing the glycerol conversions to values below 5% for prolonged reaction times. On the contrary, the La presence has favored the stability of NiCoLAG at longer reaction times, since the catalysts has a 16% of conversion in 4 consecutive cycles of uses in 72 h. Thus, the metal nanoparticles are sandwiched into a tight graphene layer structure that may act as a barrier to leaching of the nanoparticles, and thus stabilization of the NiCo nanoparticles occurs during recyclability tests. Accordingly, glycerol can react with acetic acid on the surface of Ni2+ and Co2+/Co3+ exposed sites in the NiO and Co3O4 nanoparticles form, according to XPS, Raman and TEM observations. Even if the catalysts are not porous, the redox properties of these species correlate with catalytic activity at relatively low temperatures under solvent-free conditions. Also, the low surface acidity of γ-Al2O3 helped by the La presence seems to be involved in the glycerol activation towards acetic acid to produce glycerol esters, and thereby stabilizing the catalyst. The catalytic performance of the solids in study are comparable to those of available in the literature [27,53]. The excellent stability of NiCoMAG catalyst indicates it can be reused at least four times for the production of glycerol esters. 4 Conclusions Graphene-based nanocomposites were successfully synthesized by the self-assembly method producing nanostructured metal oxides with the γ-Al2O3 phase between the separated graphene lamellar nanostructures. Basic promoters added to the composites alone with alumina were inactive in the reaction due to decreased acidity for the nanocomposites. On the contrary, the Ni and Co incorporation to the nanocomposites enhanced the Ni2+ and Co3+/Co2+ redox cycle providing good activities during the esterification of glycerol with acid acetic reaction. While the basic promoters addition such as Zn and Mg sandwiched with alumina and graphene gave poor stability to the catalysts, the La counterpart exhibited good reusability of the solid for triacetin production. This was attributed to the contribution of the graphene sheets strongly interacting with the NiCo nanoparticles and alumina providing the stabilization of the active sites against leaching. coredata.dc:description: The properties of alumina-based graphene nanocomposites were fine-tuned using a directed self-assembly of graphene oxide and metal oxides mediated by a surfactant approach. The resultant nanostructured metal oxides were evaluated in the esterification of glycerol with acetic acid as catalysts for the esters of glycerol production. X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Raman spectroscopy and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy measurements of the self-assembled nanocomposites revealed the nanocrystalline γ-Al2O3 phase between the separated graphene lamellar nanostructures. A crumpled monolayered graphene sheet along with well dispersed Ni and Co entities on solid surface appeared by Scanning electron microscopy coupled to energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) analyses. Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) showed Ni2+, Co3+/Co2+and Al3+species and a more reduced surface oxygen species in the self-assembled solids. The addition of basic promoters such as La, Mg or Zn to the composites did not improve the catalytic properties of the solids, but combined with NiCo-alumina-based graphene nanocomposites, they had shown good activities for triacetin production.
coredata.dc:title: Multifunctional properties of alumina-based graphene nanocomposites as catalysts for esters of glycerol production
